items.title: Intellij Idea + Maven: dependency version is wrong in run time
items.body:
This is driving me crazy. Originally I had added Jackson v. 2.5.4 dependency to my project. Later, I updated it to use 2.6.4 like this:

    <dependency>
        <groupId>com.fasterxml.jackson.core</groupId>
        <artifactId>jackson-core</artifactId>
        <version>2.6.4</version>
    </dependency>
    <dependency>
        <groupId>com.fasterxml.jackson.core</groupId>
        <artifactId>jackson-databind</artifactId>
        <version>2.6.4</version>
    </dependency>

When writing the code I can see that the new version features are there. Also, when I go to project settings under modules and artifacts everything there says jackson 2.6.4.

But, when I run the program, clearly it's using version 2.5.4. I see that the new feature added in 2.6.0 is not there, also I checked:

System.out.println(ObjectMapper.class.getPackage().getSpecificationVersion());

and the output is 2.5.4...

I rebuilt the project, re-imported dependencies and restarted intellij several times.... please help...

comments.body_markdown: Compilers are (almost?) never wrong about this sort of thing. You don't need to tell it to shut up, you need to (better) tell it what you meant.
comments.body: Compilers are (almost?) never wrong about this sort of thing. You don't need to tell it to shut up, you need to (better) tell it what you meant.

comments.body_markdown: Think about what the type of the whole `? :` expression is here. It'll use the combined type to resolve a single call.
comments.body: Think about what the type of the whole ? : expression is here. It'll use the combined type to resolve a single call.

comments.body_markdown: This `c.getClass()!=Commodity.class` is fishy. `getClass` returns the actual runtime class, so it will never be `Commodity`. This condition is always true
comments.body: This c.getClass()!=Commodity.class is fishy. getClass returns the actual runtime class, so it will never be Commodity. This condition is always true

comments.body_markdown: "but it obviously won't" - you may wish to think about what's "obvious".
comments.body: "but it obviously won't" - you may wish to think about what's "obvious".

comments.body_markdown: @Jorn, The problem here is that I need to call constructor, that corresponds to the type of an argument. To avoid huge expression like `A instanceof B?(B)arg : A instanceof C?(C)arg : ....` (for each subclass) I've decided to use handy statement like `arg.getClass.cast(arg)`. Isn't it called polymorphism and used in many places?
comments.body: @Jorn, The problem here is that I need to call constructor, that corresponds to the type of an argument. To avoid huge expression like A instanceof B?(B)arg : A instanceof C?(C)arg : .... (for each subclass) I've decided to use handy statement like arg.getClass.cast(arg). Isn't it called polymorphism and used in many places?

comments.body_markdown: @TechoftheAbsence It may sound clever, but if it doesn't work... The problem is that the target constructor call is chosen at *compile* time, so you just cannot do it this way.
comments.body: @TechoftheAbsence It may sound clever, but if it doesn't work... The problem is that the target constructor call is chosen at compile time, so you just cannot do it this way.

comments.body_markdown: By the way, a *proper* polymorphic design wouldn't need separate constructors for each subclass. The differentiating logic should be in the `Commodity` subclasses, not in the `Option` class.
comments.body: By the way, a proper polymorphic design wouldn't need separate constructors for each subclass. The differentiating logic should be in the Commodity subclasses, not in the Option class.

comments.body_markdown: If I had pass on instance of class `Item` (in a variable of type `Commodity`), should `getClass()` return `Item`? Or am I fundamentally wrong?
comments.body: If I had pass on instance of class Item (in a variable of type Commodity), should getClass() return Item? Or am I fundamentally wrong?

comments.body_markdown: You would be correct *at runtime*. But the constructor call is resolved at *compile time*. I suppose you *could* call that "fundamentally wrong" if you so choose ;-)
comments.body: You would be correct at runtime. But the constructor call is resolved at compile time. I suppose you could call that "fundamentally wrong" if you so choose ;-)

answers.body_markdown:
Unsurprisingly, the compiler isn't actually wrong here. Let's look at the separate parts of your code:

I'm going to assume that both `Item` and `Consumable` extend `Commodity`.

`Item.EMPTY`: We can assume this is of type `Item`.

`c.getClass().cast(c)`: This does nothing. It's always going to be of type `Commodity`.

`c.getClass()!=Commodity.class?c.getClass().cast(c):Item.EMPTY` will then resolve to the common supertype. That's `Commodity`.

The compiler has no choice but to choose the `Commodity` overload, and that's what makes it a recursive call.

All in all, what you are trying to do is call a different constructor overload based on a conditional. That's simply not possible in Java. Instead, you should make a factory method:

```
static Option create(Commodity commodity, int price) {
  return commodity instanceof Consumable ? new Option((Consumable) commodity, price) : new Option(Item.EMPTY, price);
}
answers.title: Compiler thinks that calling constructor with arg.getClass().cast(arg) is recursive, althought it wrong
answers.body:
Unsurprisingly, the compiler isn't actually wrong here. Let's look at the separate parts of your code:

I'm going to assume that both Item and Consumable extend Commodity.

Item.EMPTY: We can assume this is of type Item.

c.getClass().cast(c): This does nothing. It's always going to be of type Commodity.

c.getClass()!=Commodity.class?c.getClass().cast(c):Item.EMPTY will then resolve to the common supertype. That's Commodity.

The compiler has no choice but to choose the Commodity overload, and that's what makes it a recursive call.

All in all, what you are trying to do is call a different constructor overload based on a conditional. That's simply not possible in Java. Instead, you should make a factory method:

static Option create(Commodity commodity, int price) {
  return commodity instanceof Consumable ? new Option((Consumable) commodity, price) : new Option(Item.EMPTY, price);
}

items.title: Compiler thinks that calling constructor with arg.getClass().cast(arg) is recursive, althought it wrong
items.body:
I have an interface Commodity, that is a supertype of Item and Consumable enums. Also, there is a class Option with multiple constructors:

class Option{
    Option(Item c,int price){. . .}
    Option(Consumable c,int price){. . .}
    Option(Commodity c,int price){
        this(c.getClass()!=Commodity.class?c.getClass().cast(c):Item.EMPTY,price);
    }
}
}

Compiler thinks, that this will lead to an infinite recursion, but it obviously won't.

Recursive constructor invocation Option(Commodity, int)

How to say him "Shut up, guy, I know, what I am doing!"?

comments.body_markdown: That is correct for one to many, only a foreign key is generated. Why do you need a subject attribute in teacher?
comments.body: That is correct for one to many, only a foreign key is generated. Why do you need a subject attribute in teacher?

comments.body_markdown: Define 'correct' more clearly. What exactly do you expect from the table structure and maybe then you can look at the java entity model.
comments.body: Define 'correct' more clearly. What exactly do you expect from the table structure and maybe then you can look at the java entity model.

comments.body_markdown: *The data model (e-r model) that Dbeaver defines ... only generates the relationship in the subject table*. That is **exactly** how is should be defined in a RDBMS. It says "for a given subject I get 1 teacher and for a given teacher I get many subjects". You do not want the subject in the teacher entity. Putting it there would require an array of subjects, thus making it a M:M relationship and at the same you violate 1NF.
comments.body: The data model (e-r model) that Dbeaver defines ... only generates the relationship in the subject table. That is exactly how is should be defined in a RDBMS. It says "for a given subject I get 1 teacher and for a given teacher I get many subjects". You do not want the subject in the teacher entity. Putting it there would require an array of subjects, thus making it a M:M relationship and at the same you violate 1NF.

items.title: Bidirectional relationship OneToMany in Java Entity
items.body:
I am working with Jakarta (JPA) and postgres. I use DBeaver as a database manager. I have two entities defined, teacher and subject.

The relationship between them is, a teacher can teach several subjects, but a subject can only be taught by one teacher, this is a 1:N relationship in the sense of teacher and subject. I have modeled this with Jakarta, as follows:

@Entity
@Table(name = "teacher")
@Data
@Builder
@AllArgsConstructor
@NoArgsConstructor 
public class Teacher {

    @Id
    @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.UUID)
    @Column(name = "id", updatable = false, nullable = false)
    @EqualsAndHashCode.Include
    private String id;

    @OneToMany(targetEntity = Subject.class, cascade = CascadeType.ALL, orphanRemoval = true, fetch = FetchType.EAGER)
    @JsonManagedReference
    private Set<Subject> subject;
    }

and

@Entity
@Table(name = "subject")
@Data
@Builder
@AllArgsConstructor
@NoArgsConstructor 
public class Subject {

@Id
@GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.UUID)
@Column(name = "id", updatable = false, nullable = false)
@EqualsAndHashCode.Include
private String id;

@ManyToOne(fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
    @OnDelete(action = OnDeleteAction.CASCADE)
    @JoinColumn(name = "teacher", referencedColumnName = "id", foreignKey = @ForeignKey(name="fk_teacher_subject"))
    @JsonBackReference
    private Teacher teacher;
}

However, the data model (e-r model) that Dbeaver defines when starting the microservice only generates the relationship in the subject table, that is, I need my teacher table to contain a subject attribute and also for the subject table to contain an attribute teacher.

the relationship tags oneToMany and manyToOne are correctly defined.

After searching for information, I added the @JsonManagedReference and @JsonBackReference tags in each of the entities to indicate which entity is the parent (Teacher) and child (Subject)

Why is the 'subject' attribute not generated correctly in Teacher?

comments.body_markdown: Please clarify your specific problem or provide additional details to highlight exactly what you need. As it's currently written, it's hard to tell exactly what you're asking.
comments.body: Please clarify your specific problem or provide additional details to highlight exactly what you need. As it's currently written, it's hard to tell exactly what you're asking.

answers.body_markdown:
You are trying the "inject" a value but not via a variable - so the
error you are getting is telling you, that there is no variable named
`BBRr0...`.

Use proper variable name like `app.push.pubkey`

`@Value("${app.push.pubkey}") private String publicKey`

And add it in your `application.yml` or `application.properties` with
the test value.

`app.push.pubkey=BBRr0...`

Or if you absolutely must, use the test-key as a fallback, if the var is
missing:

`@Value("${app.push.pubkey:BBRr0...}") private String publicKey`

And add it in your application.yml or application.properties with the test value.

app.push.pubkey=BBRr0...

Or if you absolutely must, use the test-key as a fallback, if the var is missing:

@Value("${app.push.pubkey:BBRr0...}") private String publicKey

answers.title: How to add rest API request time out in OAuth2RestTemplate in spring boot?
answers.body:
Ensure these dependencies

<groupId>org.apache.httpcomponents</groupId>
<artifactId>httpclient</artifactId>

Configure the HttpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory bean and then inject it into your OAuth2RestTemplate bean:

@Configuration
public class ResourceConfig {

    @Bean
    public HttpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory clientHttpRequestFactory() {
        HttpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory factory = new HttpComponentsClientHttpRequestFactory();
        factory.setConnectTimeout(5000); // 5 seconds
        factory.setReadTimeout(5000);    // 5 seconds
        return factory;
    }

    @Bean
    public OAuth2RestTemplate oAuth2RestTemplate() {
        ResourceOwnerPasswordResourceDetails resourceDetails = new ResourceOwnerPasswordResourceDetails();
        resourceDetails.setAccessTokenUri("YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN_URI");
        resourceDetails.setClientId("YOUR_CLIENT_ID");
        resourceDetails.setClientSecret("YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET");
        resourceDetails.setClientAuthenticationScheme(AuthenticationScheme.header);

        OAuth2RestTemplate restTemplate = new OAuth2RestTemplate(resourceDetails);
        restTemplate.setRequestFactory(clientHttpRequestFactory());
        
        return restTemplate;
    }
}

items.title: How to add rest API request time out in OAuth2RestTemplate in spring boot?
items.body:
In my spring boot microservices, I am using OAuth2RestTemplate to make rest API call. Now, We have to add request time out in rest api call and for that I tried spring.mvc.async.request-timeout=20000 in application.properties file but did not work.

@Configuration
public class ResourceConfig {

   @Bean
   @LoadBalanced
   @Qualifier("oauth2BalancedRestTemplate")
   public OAuth2RestTemplate oauth2BalancedRestTemplate(@Qualifier("oauth2RestTemplate") OAuth2RestTemplate bean) {
      OAuth2RestTemplate restTemplate = new OAuth2RestTemplate(bean.getResource());
      restTemplate.setRequestFactory(bean.getRequestFactory());
      return restTemplate;
   }
   
   @Bean
   @LoadBalanced
   @Qualifier("oauth2JWTBalancedRestTemplate")
   public OAuth2RestTemplate oauth2JWTBalancedRestTemplate(@Qualifier("oauth2JWTRestTemplate") OAuth2RestTemplate bean) {
      OAuth2RestTemplate restTemplate = new OAuth2RestTemplate(bean.getResource());
      restTemplate.setRequestFactory(bean.getRequestFactory());
      return restTemplate;
   } 
}

@Service
public class ApiCall {

   @Value("${url}")
   private String uri;
   
   @Value("${endpoint}")
   private String endpoint;
   
   @Autowired
   @Qualifier("oauth2JWTBalancedRestTemplate")
   private OAuth2RestTemplate restTemplate;

   public Response getTrdDetail(Request req) {
     HttpHeaders headers = new HttpHeaders();
     HttpEntity<Request> httpEntity = new HttpEntity<Request> (req, headers);
     return restTemplate.exchange(uri + endpoint, HttpMethod.POST, httpEntity, Response.class);
   
   }
}

items.body_markdown:
I am trying to call a stored procedure which looks like this:

    create or replace procedure my_stored_procedure(
       xIds bigint[],
       yIds bigint[]
    )

I am trying to call from Spring Data JPA as follows:

    @Query(value = "CALL my_stored_procedure(:xIds,:yIds);", nativeQuery = true)
    void deleteArchivedAgents(List<Long> xIds, List<Long> yIds);


It is giving me an error: `ERROR: procedure my_stored_procedure(bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint) does not exist. Hint: No procedure matches the given name and argument types. You might need to add explicit type casts.`

I know that the corresponding data type for `long` in postgresql is `bigint`. Not sure how to cast the long data type in java to bigint in postgresql.

Note: The reason it is saying that `procedure my_stored_procedure(bigint, bigint, bigint, bigint) does not exist` is because each list has data of size 2.

Any help is appreciated.
